Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Award: Role of Migration in Social Complexity

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration: Ms. Katie Richards and Dr. Andrew Duff, of Washington State University, will explore how identity is created, maintained, and expressed in frontier zones as they explore the origins and social organization of a native pre-Hispanic group, referred to today as Fremont, They lived across much of what is today the state of Utah. Archaeologists have studied the Fremont for over a century; however, there is still considerable debate over who the Fremont were and where they came from. This project will address fundamental, big-picture questions about Fremont to help create a new foundational understanding about this group. Located at the northern fringes of the more densely populated North American Southwest, the Fremont region is ideally situated to explore how identity was negotiated and created in prehistoric frontier zones. The academic debate over who the Fremont were has also proved a stumbling block to educators teaching Utah state history. Little information on the Fremont has been published for a public audience. Ms. Richards will work with 4th grade teachers (the year when Utah state history is taught) to create lesson plans that will help educators more effectively teach about Utah’s priceless cultural heritage and prehistory. <br/><br/>Ms. Richards and Dr. Duff will use pottery to explore Fremont origins, social organization, and identity in this northern frontier of the North American Southwest. Frontier studies provide a dynamic and powerful way to explore how identity is formed, negotiated, and maintained in regions where disparate traditions meet, and will be used to explore the complex blend of innovation and tradition present in Fremont material culture. Using both high- and low- technology methods, the researchers will use a multi-scalar approach to better understand Fremont. At the broadest scale, the researchers will evaluate how Fremont fits into the larger history of the American Southwest. Using attributes of Fremont and Southwestern pottery, they will explore potential origins of the Fremont ceramic tradition and assess whether painted ceramic technology was brought into the region as a result of migration or was a locally produced emulation. They will then use instrumental neutron activation analysis to chemically characterize Fremont pottery and reconstruct Fremont production and exchange networks at a regional scale. At the finest scale, they will explore how painted ceramics were used within villages across the region. Combined, these analyses will create a robust and more complete understanding of complexity and origins in this frontier zone.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Fremont people were a sedentary or partially sedentary agricultural group who occupied much of the state of Utah between AD 400 and 1350. They lived in villages and had complex trade networks both within the region and as far reaching as the Gulf of California; however, what ‘Fremont’ means and the relationship between the Fremont region and the larger Southwest has been the subject of debate for over a century. Some scholars have argued that the archaeological remains are so varied at Fremont sites that Fremont is a useless term. They argue that no large-scale Fremont identity could have existed. Many scholars have also argued that Fremont peoples developed with minimal influence from neighboring Ancestral Puebloan groups to the south. More recently some archaeologists have suggested that a Fremont identity did exist and that it was not only influenced by neighboring Puebloan groups, but that Fremont culture actually originated from Ancestral Puebloans migrating north. It has been difficult to further Fremont studies without answering these basic questions of Fremont origins and identity. This project aimed to address these complex but foundational questions using both Fremont and Ancestral Puebloan painted pottery. The pottery was examined using a variety of low and high technology methods to look at the chemical composition and design techniques of the two pottery types. These data provided insights into where the pottery was produced and how similar different types of pottery were. The analyses demonstrated that Fremont peoples across the region interacted and shared certain ideological frameworks concerning painted pottery procurement, production, and use. This suggests that Fremont peoples living at different villages across the region, on some level, shared an identity. Painted designs on the pottery were less conclusive. While they suggest a strong influence from and connection to neighboring Ancestral Puebloan groups, it is unclear whether that connection is representative of migrants or simply one neighboring group attempting to emulate the other. Despite the exact nature of the relationship, it is clear that the Ancestral Puebloan Southwest was very influential on Fremont peoples. While more questions remain, this project helped address foundational questions about Fremont identity and origins that future researchers can build on. This project was also designed to provide Utah educators with more information on Utah’s indigenous cultures and rich cultural heritage. Few publications have been written about the Fremont for the general public. This project has allowed for collaboration with fourth grade teachers in Utah to create lesson plans to more accurately teach about Fremont peoples. The results of this project have helped answer long standing questions about Fremont origins and social organization as well as provide resources to help the public better understand and appreciate the rich and complex cultural heritage present in Utah.
